title: Transcriptomics

source.description:
Dilute an overnight culture of B. mycoides to OD600=0.05 in LB. Divide the culture in 2 parts.
Supplement one of them with solanine (concentration range from
to
) . Keep the other one as a negative control.
Culture the cells for
Collect cells by spinning down at
Wash cells with PBS at room temperature.

Remove the PBS and add freshly made basic cell culture media containing
formaldehyde to cross-link the DNA-protein complexes.

Incubate for
with gentle agitation on a rocking platform.
Remove the fixation solution by spinning down at .

To quench the reaction, for cell count of 1-5 million, add
glycine solution. (!glycine solution concentration dependent on cell count)

Incubate at
with gentle agitation on a rocking platform.

Remove the glycine solution by
. Discard the
supernatant. The pellet can be frozen at
after adding
of Protease Inhibitor Cocktail (PIC).

To lyse the cells, for cell count of 1-5 million, add
of Hypotonic Buffer; Resuspend the cells and
incubate at
.

Centrifuge the hypotonic slurries at
to collect the nuclei.

For cell count of 1-5 million, add
of Digestion Buffer to the nuclei, immediately followed by
adding
of PIC to each sample.

Add Micrococcal Nuclease to each sample to digest the DNA. Mix by inverting the tube several times
and incubate at
. Mix by inversion every 3-5 minutes. The amount and incubation
time of Micrococcal Nuclease required to digest the genomic DNA to an optimal 150 900 bp length
may need to be determined empirically for individual cell types.

Stop digestion by adding
of
EDTA per sample and place the sample on ice.

Pellet nuclei by centrifugation at
.
Discard the supernatant.

Resuspend nuclear pellet in Lysis Buffer and incubate the sample
to lyse the
nuclei. Alternatively, sonicate to shear the DNA. The time and strength for sonication may need to be
determined empirically.

Centrifuge the sample at
.
Transfer the supernatant to a clean dry microcentrifuge tube.

Add
of PIC to each sample and mix.

Chromatin sample is now ready for ChIP Assay. If the sample is not to be used immediately, store at
.
It is recommended that the shearing efficiency is analyzed at this stage to ensure that 150-900bp fragments are obtained during shearing the DNA to increase the ChIP efficiency.

Mix the Chromatin Sample, Protease Inhibitor Cocktail (PIC), optimal quantity of BioLegend’s Go-
ChIP-GradeTM Purified antibodies and add Column Conditioning Buffer to make final
slurries.
Gently rotate at
for
**incubation can also be extended
.

Prepare the high-throughput (HT) Protein A or G 96 well plate or Spin Column by adding
of
Column Conditioning Buffer in each well or column and allow it to flow through via gravity (~
).
Discard the flow-through and repeat steps 18 and 19.

Remove the slurries from the rotator following
incubation and briefly spin down to remove
residual liquid from the caps.

Load the entire
slurries and allow to flow completely through the high-throughput (HT) Protein
A or G 96 well plate or Spin Column at room temperature (approximate
).

Add
of Wash Buffer 1 to each well or column and centrifuge at
for plate, or
for column, for
at
. Discard the flow through and repeat once.

Add
of Wash Buffer 2 to each well or column and centrifuge at
for plate, or
for column, for
at
. Discard the flow through and repeat once.

Add
of Wash Buffer 3 to each well or column and centrifuge at
for plate, or
for column, for
at
. Discard the flow through and repeat once.

Spin dry at
for the plate or
for the column for one minute at room temperature to
remove any remaining liquid from the membrane of the plate or column. Place a clean 96 well
collection plate or a collection tube beneath the plate or column.

Add
of Elution Buffer to each well or column. Incubate at room temperature for
.

Centrifuge the plate or column at
for the plate, or
for the column, for
at
to collect the eluted chromatin-protein complex.

To each eluted sample, add
of 1M NaHCO3,
NaCl and
of Distilled Water. Mix thoroughly and incubate at
on the heat block for two hours or the incubation time can be extended to overnight.

Remove the sample from the heat block, add
of Proteinase K to each sample, vortex briefly and
perform a short spin down. Incubate at
for
.

Add
of Proteinase K Stop Solution to each sample, vortex briefly and perform a short spin down.

Purify the DNA by QIAquick™ PCR purification kit, according to manufacturer’s manual. Purified DNA
is ready for downstream real-time qPCR analysis.

description:
The potato root secretes root exudates, a mixture of organic molecules out of which solanine is found in the highest concentration (range of ug/ml). Also, solanine is a molecule specifically found in the root exudate of potato plants, which makes it a good candidate for a dependecy molecule which will ensure that Bacillus mycoides doesn't escape the designated action area. Studies have shown that there are soil bacteria able to metabolize solanine as a carbon source. Unfortunately, we weren't able to find an already described solanine-inducing promoter. Because the natural habitat of B. mycoides is the potato rhizosphere, we have strong reasons to believe that if such a promoter may already be present in its genome.
In order to find this promoter, we designed a CHIP-Seq experiment. B. mycoides will be incubated with a different range of solanine concentrations. The DNA will be extracted and the CHIP-Seq technique will be used to detect potential binding sites of solanine operators using monoclonal anti-solanine antibodies.
